p: Regardless of age, AR wP-M males compromised the hatchability of all of the eggs produced by the wild-type females they mated with ( Table 2). Instead, the reverse crosses (S ANG males × AR wP-M females) gave age-dependant results with egg fertility values gradually increasing from 0.09 ± 0.05 to 17.29 ± 2.32 when S ANG males were, respectively, 3 and 17days (±1) old. AR wP-M males demonstrated higher mating competitiveness compared to the wild-types presenting the same genetic background as shown by the measured level of CI corr and by the Fried competitiveness index ( Table 2) which was significantly higher than 1 (F (1,4) = 11.24; P = 0.028).
